story:
On Wed, Feb 13, 2013 at 1:46 PM, DeAndra Rodriguez <rodriguezdeandra@gmail.com> wrote:

 

Have you ever had to face the BATTLE with CANCER?

There are many people who have lost someone they dearly loved to the battle with cancer. As if fighting cancer itself is not troublesome enough, cancer victims have to fight for the safest possible treatments also. The most commonly recommended cancer treatment, chemo therapy, has less than therapeutic effects on the cancer patient. It is scientifically proven to possess toxic properties but it is the primary insurance covered form of treatment. The holistic ways of treatment are not insurance covered, and forces patients to accept a treatment they did not choose for themselves. I have provided links below for examples of the toxicity of chemo therapy. 

 

Our grandmother Margie Beatty has suffered over 5 years of a constant cancer battle. She is a lovely 63 year old woman who is embraced by many people within our community in which we live. Margie is full of life, with a very warming aura that people love to be around. She has such a giving spirit, and finally she is at the point in life where she needs other kind and giving people to return the love. We have tried everything we could to help the situation ourselves, but holistic treatment is very costly. She really wants to try holistic treatment instead of using chemicals, and that is why we have turned to you guys for support. Please help her cause with whatever contributions are laid on your hearts, she will be forever thankful. 

 
   With much love and embrace,
 
   DeAndra Rodriguez 

 

 chemo toxicity articles : 
  • http://www.naturalnews.com/036725_chemotherapy_cancer_tumors_backfires.html 

  •  http://www.naturalnews.com/038811_chemotherapy_tumor_growth_fraud.html 

     

how you can help? 

We have calculated that in order to get the correct amount of treatment to help our grandmother Margie, we need 16,500 or more.  There is a 5,500 per week of treatment charge and she has a recommended stay of at least 3 weeks. This amount does not include general well nutrition for future treatments when she returns home. I know that sounds like a lot but its not impossible. I Have provided a link that estimates the exact amount she needs for the Gerson treatment. Her insurance does not cover holistic therapy and we want to help keep her alive and happy by what she believes will make her happy.   

  • http://gerson.org/gerpress/clinica-nutricion-y-vida/

 

Comments, Concerns and questions can be emailed to:   

margiebeatty11@yahoo.com  

 

Sincerely , DeAndra Rodriguez(grand daughter) Of Margie beatty

story_txt:
On Wed, Feb 13, 2013 at 1:46 PM, DeAndra Rodriguez <rodriguezdeandra@gmail.com> wrote:

 
Have you ever had to face the BATTLE with CANCER?
There are many people who have lost someone they dearly loved to the battle with cancer. As if fighting cancer itself is not troublesome enough, cancer victims have to fight for the safest possible treatments also. The most commonly recommended cancer treatment, chemo therapy, has less than therapeutic effects on the cancer patient. It is scientifically proven to possess toxic properties but it is the primary insurance covered form of treatment. The holistic ways of treatment are not insurance covered, and forces patients to accept a treatment they did not choose for themselves. I have provided links below for examples of the toxicity of chemo therapy. 
 
Our grandmother Margie Beatty has suffered over 5 years of a constant cancer battle. She is a lovely 63 year old woman who is embraced by many people within our community in which we live. Margie is full of life, with a very warming aura that people love to be around. She has such a giving spirit, and finally she is at the point in life where she needs other kind and giving people to return the love. We have tried everything we could to help the situation ourselves, but holistic treatment is very costly. She really wants to try holistic treatment instead of using chemicals, and that is why we have turned to you guys for support. Please help her cause with whatever contributions are laid on your hearts, she will be forever thankful. 


 
   With much love and embrace,
 
   DeAndra Rodriguez 


 

 chemo toxicity articles : 



http://www.naturalnews.com/036725_chemotherapy_cancer_tumors_backfires.html 



 http://www.naturalnews.com/038811_chemotherapy_tumor_growth_fraud.html 
 


how you can help? 

We have calculated that in order to get the correct amount of treatment to help our grandmother Margie, we need 16,500 or more.  There is a 5,500 per week of treatment charge and she has a recommended stay of at least 3 weeks. This amount does not include general well nutrition for future treatments when she returns home. I know that sounds like a lot but its not impossible. I Have provided a link that estimates the exact amount she needs for the Gerson treatment. Her insurance does not cover holistic therapy and we want to help keep her alive and happy by what she believes will make her happy.   

http://gerson.org/gerpress/clinica-nutricion-y-vida/


 
Comments, Concerns and questions can be emailed to:   
margiebeatty11@yahoo.com  
 
Sincerely , DeAndra Rodriguez(grand daughter) Of Margie beatty

story:
Summary

I started getting into running the week my Dad passed away in August. I had completed a 5k in washington in the top 5% and came back to see my Dad had a cancer that had taken over much of his body. He died the next day after I came to see him in the hospital. What made things worse was that he had no life insurance, leaving my Mother to sell much of her possessions and having to come to the conclusion to not pay her mortgage anymore and in a short time will have to foreclose on the house me and my brother grew up in.

I handled much of the details of my Father's passing, funeral arrangements, letting friends and family know, and most importantly comforting my Mother. Running had now turned into a way of therapy because I didn't know what to do about my Mom losing her house.

However, it turned out I was actually not that bad at running. I started finishing in the top 5% and then the top 3 finishers, and then most recently I finished the Tough Mudder race in Seattle in the top 5% qualifying me for the World's Toughest Mudder race in New Jersey in November. Here you have 24 hours to complete as many laps of an 8 mile obstacle course in the cold weather.

If I'm the top finisher, I win $15,000 and that could really help my Mom. I'm going to try my hardest to win, and use my family as motivation, and even though this is a once in a lifetime opportunity to just go to the race, I really just want the chance to win for my Mom, who deserves to have her house.

I'm asking $2000 for airfare, hotel, travel to the site of the race, the race fee ($500) and the price of a go pro camera to film it.

What You Get

So there are several ways you can help me.

If you donate $10 to my cause I will send you a signed picture of me at the race letting you know how much it means to me.

If you donate $25 to my cause I will send you a video personally thanking you for your help.

If you donate $100 to my cause and I am able to raise enough money to go to the race and film it I will send you a personally copy of the race you helped me with. Also, I will send you a picture of me at the race, with a personal message thanking you for your contribution.

Along with all of these things, you also get the satisfaction that you are helping out a family who really does need your help.

The Impact

Any donation will make me so happy to know that people want to help my Mom. She is a great loving person, and truly anything helps us. The impact of what that prize money could do for my Mom is buy her time for me and my brothers to raise more money in the future to help her. I think it's best to ask for help to win the money for the house, then ask for the money for the house. I know we're in a tight spot and I don't want to trouble anyone else with more than what we can maybe do ourselves, at least for now.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand if you can't contribute any funds to our cause but if you could let other people know, and spread the word on the inter webs about it, it would either make or break this campaign.

Please either post on your facebook, twitter, tumblr, or use the indiegogo share tools.

Thank you for reading the details for this campaign and hopefully good things will come!

story:
In the Fall of 2005, everything changed in our lives.  Caitlin had just received the news that her ovarian cancerous tumors would return...for a third time.  After two prior surgeries, the doctors told us that with the next surgery,  they would need to remove what was left of Caitlin’s ovaries. This obviously was not the type of news you would want to receive as a 21-year-old female with no kids; the news that you would never be able to naturally conceive your own child.  Oh, and this was the first few months of our relationship!  We went through a lot our first year of dating, to say the least, and it has only made us stronger.  After Caitlin's surgery, and multiple failed attempts at freezing fertilized eggs before the surgery, we had come to terms with the fact that we wouldn't be able to have children naturally.  Adoption has always been something that we wanted to pursue, and it is still something we will pursue in the future.  But there is something about being pregnant and giving birth yourself that is so so special.  As a male, I don't completely understand it, but seeing Caitlin in tears as she talks about how great the experience of being pregnant will be, I kinda get it.  It is important and it is something we want to try.  We love children and we get to work with kids every day in our careers.  Caitlin as a kindergarten teacher and me as an elementary assistant principal, we find joy in helping little ones.  But we feel it's time we had a little one of our own.  IVF is our only option for Caitlin to become pregnant, as she can no longer produce eggs herself.  We are so excited and blessed that her little sister, Dancey, has agreed to be our egg donor.  There is something amazing in the fact that she is so selflessly giving a part of her to help us out in a time of need. But, now comes the hard part, raising the money.  IVF is an expensive procedure, as you'll see below, and insurance doesn't cover it (imagine that).  So we are calling on friends and family to help us out.  We appreciate anything that you are able to give and we think it's really cool that each of you will have a part in creating a new life with us.

What We Need & What You Get

We need financial help!! There are many many fees incurred with IVF ranging from the consultation and doctor visits ($200 each) to ultra sounds, cycle monitoring ($3,000) lab fees ($4,000-$5,000), medicine/hormones ($3000-$4000) and several other fees! We have been lucky enough to find an egg donor (my little sister!), which will save us thousands of dollars, but our baby will still be an expensive baby! You will see many perks that we are able to offer based on your contribution - it is a small way to show our appreciation. 

The Impact

There aren't many words that can truly express what your help will do for Brian and I! We both have intentions of more children (adopted) in the future, but wanted one chance to experience the adventure of pregnancy! We have spent years working with children - first in a church setting and now on a daily basis in the school setting. Brian and I absolutely love our careers and find no better feeling than helping guide and love the children in our schools. As we continue to do this for other children in our career, we are ready to begin this in our life away from work, with our own child :)

If we do not make our goal, we still get to keep what we earn! Our total cost during this process will most likely exceed $15,000 - therefore, if we earn more than our goal, it will go towards additional IVF costs.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether or not your are able to contribute financially, we can use your support!! Please pass along our story and our website - we welcome help from all! And we THANK YOU so very much :)

story:
We are the people behind Camp Kita—Isaiah, Morgan and Sydney. We are siblings who are trying to establish a non-profit to help the children of suicide. Suicide affected our family in July of 2001. That night, our mom gathered us all in the dark living room and broke the news that our father chose to kill himself, leaving the three of us kids behind. While we’re sure that was probably the worst conversation our mom has ever had to initiate, that was basically the only time we discussed it as a family. The three of us independently internalized it for years. Despite our separate approaches to dealing with the grief,  we all felt the same emotions as most kids dealing with this would—guilt, anger, sadness, and embarrassment, though none us had the financial means or available resources to cope with these feelings in a healthy way.

Camp Kita’s mission is to provide a happy place for children of suicide; where they can connect with other kids sharing the same grief and find normalcy and constructive ways to deal with the pain of losing a parent to suicide.

In order to make this camp possible and accessible for our campers, we need to start at “square one” with our funding. This is where we need sponsors like you! The funding that we are asking for would go towards the cost of starting up a non-profit, getting established with the IRS and getting Camp Kita off the ground. 

Although we may not reach our financial goals through this venue, any money raised will go towards the start-up costs of legitimizing the program as a non-profit.

 

Thank you! We can’t wait for Camp Kita to make the impact we know it will.

story:
4:09:43

Raising money for victims of the Boston Marathon bombing.

Three people were killed and over 170 injured in the Boston Marathon bombing on 15th April 2013. Many of those 170 have been grievously hurt and these innocent victims are facing long periods of medical treatment and rehabilitation. Many of them will require alterations to their houses and expensive prosthetics, and some of them might need long-term care. I am asking that you sponsor me to run the London Marathon this Sunday (21st April). All money raised will be divided equally between the Mayor of Boston's One Fund, a general fund to assist victims of the bombs, and the Challenged Athletes Foundation's Boston fund, which will help with rehabilitation of those left disabled after the attack.

Why am I doing this?

I have been involved in various endurance sports for many years and have spent more time than most hanging around marathon finish lines. When the bombs went off in Boston I felt that my community had been attacked. I had been given a place for the London Marathon but I had withdrawn a few weeks ago because I wasn't happy with my training, so on Tuesday morning I phoned the London Marathon organisers, explained that I wanted to reactivate my entry so that I could raise money for the Boston survivors and they agreed.

Why indiegogo?

I'm using Indiegogo for several reasons. Firstly, I can't use the UK charitable sites such as JustGiving or Virgin Money Giving because these funds are brand new and not registered with them. I can't use the American sites like FirstGiving because I'm not in the US. Hence Indiegogo. Once it's all done and dusted they'll transfer the money to me and I'll donate it straight to the two charities named above. Indiegogo charge a small percentage (4%) which is actually less than JustGiving (5%), but I will put in £100 to start with which will cover all of that so you can be sure that all of your donation goes where it's meant to go.

story:
***UPDATE***

 If you would like to see my progress on the drawings I'll be sending to donors or you want an idea of what you might be recieving, you can see them here.

_________________________________________________________

Hi, my name is Gianni. I'm a really average working class kid who likes the Bruins, goes to art school.... and I'm currently trying to transition from female to male. I'm a painter and musician in Boston, Massachusetts. I'm also very sick, I have countless severe allergies and I also suffer from fibromyalgia.

My health issues make it very difficult for me to hold a job or even get a job; I'm very limited in the kinds of work I can actually do. Because of my health, I had to completely ignore being transgender for several years. But now I am finally healthy enough to focus on my gender and transitioning. I am currently in gender therapy and I still need to be approved for hormone treatment, as my health issues are drawing out the process. The only real issue is, I have no steady income. I sell a painting here and there, but it's not even close to enough to pay for copays, new clothes, binders, etc.

This fund is mostly for social transitioning things, things that will aid me in passing as male. I have to change my entire wardrobe and I also need binders and a decent, comfortable stp. It is also for my copays and costs of transition related physicals, blood tests, etc. If you contribute, you will be making an enormous impact on my life. My quality of life will increase dramatically. If the goal amount isn't reached, any acquired funds will still go towards transitioning. I'm really just trying to be able to live a normal, comfortable life.

I will be sending out these perk gifts after the campaign deadline ends.

  • I want everyone to know how much I appreciate their support so anyone who donates $10 or more will get an original work of art! You can see my work at http://www.facebook.com/paintingsbygemma and http://gemmaparabicoli.deviantart.com to get an idea of what you may be getting. (On my websites, most of my recent works are elaborate figure studies because I am in the process of preparing for a major figure/portrait series project.) 
  • If you donate $50 - $99, you'll be getting an original oil pastel drawing of something nice like a nature scene or an animal. These can be custom! I specialize in stylized surreal and abstract work so those are also options. Email me at paintingsbygemma@yahoo.com if there is something specific you want. If you don't want anything specific and just want something random, don't email me and I'll just draw something up for you.
  • If you can donate $100 or more, which is the most amazing thing that could ever happen to me, you'll be getting a custom oil painting. You will be getting an oil painting on a stretched canvas I built myself. These are completely custom, so basically I'll be doing a discounted commission to show you how much I really do appreciate you're incredible help. Email me at paintingsbygemma@yahoo.com and tell me what you want a painting of. I can even color-coordinate the painting to a room you would want to hang it in. Please note that it will take a few weeks to get an oil painting. Since these are custom, I have to build the canvas, prime the canvas, do the painting, and I also have to wait for it to be completely dry and then varnish it before it can ship.

Thank you so much for looking at my campaign. I know not everyone who wants to help is able to, and that's okay. If you want to help but cannot help financially, please share this campaign. I appreciate any support at all.

story:
Elka's Story

Elka's dream - if you couldn't guess, or don't know us, Elka is my wife. My dreams have always been big and lofty, build an awesome software product when I get out of school next year, get hired by google, or the next facebook, rack up stock options and retire rich.

My wife's dream...much simpler, but no less important : be a mommy.

This is a realizable dream now, as we're on the verge of adopting two amazing foster children as long as everything fans out. It may fall through.... but she wants to go through pregnancy, and feels 'less of a woman' because this is one thing she cannot do, that most other women can. 

Elka has a list of health issues that not only inhibit her ability to conceive, but also inhibit her health and longevity. The fact is if her health doesn't improve, she may not be with us in the next 10 years.

Some of her diagnoses include: PCOS(Poly-cystic Ovarian Syndrome), Diabetes, genetic disposition for COPD, and high-likelihood of developing cancerous cells.

To keep her health in check she has been on hormone therapy for a couple of years, but her doctors are urging her to get off those as soon as possible because it will most likely cause her cancer to come back which we definitely don't want to happen.

So she has two options : Get a hysterectomy and forever give up the dream of motherhood(the traditional way, and the joys of pregnancy, and raising from day 1), or get the vertical sleeve gastrectomy surgery.

One of the major things that controls her PCOS / Diabetes is insulin resistence, by getting gastric sleeve even though she is not considered morbidly obese it has been shown to greatly reduce and even get rid of diabetes symptoms completely, which will also highly likely get rid of the PCOS symptoms, and basically kill a lot of birds with one stone.

Her chances of conception will go through the roof, no more diabetes or PCOS symptoms, and no more hormone therapy. 

Sadly, self-pay for vertical sleeve gastrectomy is expensive. Plus we've requested enough to also do our first round of in-vitro following surgery.

A Message From Elka

Firstly I'd like to thank EVERYBODY who has reached out in support of my cause, and helped create this fundraising campaign. May God bless you and keep you strong for your commitment in helping me reach my goal, and become a mother. To each and every person who blogs about this, shares it on Facebook, Twitter, etc, you are my heroes!

My heartfelt gratitude goes out to everyone who gives even the smallest amount. Maybe you know what it's like to be child-less and struggling to conceive, or you know someone in the same boat. It's hard most days, seeing other happy mom's with their bundles of joy sends me into a dark depression, and I don't want to feel that way anymore. I don't want to have this pent up frustration over my lack-of children. Don't get me wrong, I love my foster children, very much, but they could go back anyday, and that will be a huge pain in and of itself.

Becoming a mommy is my purpose in life, and if I can't live to reach my purpose, then can life be worth living? These are questions I ask daily, thank you so much for delivering me from this curse, and helping me to become healthier.

Your Contributions

Thank you in advance for your contributions and support. It is deeply appreciated and will guarantee you good karma and blessings from God. 100% of your contribution will support Elka's Gastric Sleeve surgery, related expenses, and round 1 of IVF.

Note : Elka's actual surgery is estimated to cost $20,000, but we've set our goal at $25,000 to cover round 1 of IVF, and also cover the IndieGoGo processing fees, and other costs this surgery might have on our family including food, medicine, vitamins, etc.

Paypal payments are preferred as they are available much faster and will help us reach our goal faster. Credit card payments won't hit until after the fundraiser is completed.

HOW YOU CAN HELP

Donations, donations, donations! + Share, Share, Share! All amounts help, and every share is 'almost' as good as a donation! Spread the word, and we may reach our goal and become parents. Please pass this on so you can help give Elka the gift of motherhood.

THE 'PERKS'

Please Note: Elka sells cupcakes from her cottage bakery and is not legally able to sell goods across state lines. As such all perks are to be considered FREE gifts from one person to another person, and not a 'purchase' for services rendered.

Cupcakes

Cookies
story_txt:
Elka's Story
Elka's dream - if you couldn't guess, or don't know us, Elka is my wife. My dreams have always been big and lofty, build an awesome software product when I get out of school next year, get hired by google, or the next facebook, rack up stock options and retire rich.
My wife's dream...much simpler, but no less important : be a mommy.
This is a realizable dream now, as we're on the verge of adopting two amazing foster children as long as everything fans out. It may fall through.... but she wants to go through pregnancy, and feels 'less of a woman' because this is one thing she cannot do, that most other women can. 
Elka has a list of health issues that not only inhibit her ability to conceive, but also inhibit her health and longevity. The fact is if her health doesn't improve, she may not be with us in the next 10 years.
Some of her diagnoses include: PCOS(Poly-cystic Ovarian Syndrome), Diabetes, genetic disposition for COPD, and high-likelihood of developing cancerous cells.
To keep her health in check she has been on hormone therapy for a couple of years, but her doctors are urging her to get off those as soon as possible because it will most likely cause her cancer to come back which we definitely don't want to happen.
So she has two options : Get a hysterectomy and forever give up the dream of motherhood(the traditional way, and the joys of pregnancy, and raising from day 1), or get the vertical sleeve gastrectomy surgery.
One of the major things that controls her PCOS / Diabetes is insulin resistence, by getting gastric sleeve even though she is not considered morbidly obese it has been shown to greatly reduce and even get rid of diabetes symptoms completely, which will also highly likely get rid of the PCOS symptoms, and basically kill a lot of birds with one stone.
Her chances of conception will go through the roof, no more diabetes or PCOS symptoms, and no more hormone therapy. 
Sadly, self-pay for vertical sleeve gastrectomy is expensive. Plus we've requested enough to also do our first round of in-vitro following surgery.
A Message From Elka
Firstly I'd like to thank EVERYBODY who has reached out in support of my cause, and helped create this fundraising campaign. May God bless you and keep you strong for your commitment in helping me reach my goal, and become a mother. To each and every person who blogs about this, shares it on Facebook, Twitter, etc, you are my heroes!
My heartfelt gratitude goes out to everyone who gives even the smallest amount. Maybe you know what it's like to be child-less and struggling to conceive, or you know someone in the same boat. It's hard most days, seeing other happy mom's with their bundles of joy sends me into a dark depression, and I don't want to feel that way anymore. I don't want to have this pent up frustration over my lack-of children. Don't get me wrong, I love my foster children, very much, but they could go back anyday, and that will be a huge pain in and of itself.
Becoming a mommy is my purpose in life, and if I can't live to reach my purpose, then can life be worth living? These are questions I ask daily, thank you so much for delivering me from this curse, and helping me to become healthier.
Your Contributions
Thank you in advance for your contributions and support. It is deeply appreciated and will guarantee you good karma and blessings from God. 100% of your contribution will support Elka's Gastric Sleeve surgery, related expenses, and round 1 of IVF.
Note : Elka's actual surgery is estimated to cost $20,000, but we've set our goal at $25,000 to cover round 1 of IVF, and also cover the IndieGoGo processing fees, and other costs this surgery might have on our family including food, medicine, vitamins, etc.

story:
Help for Mom

One of the most kind and generous women I know, now needs help!

My Mother Carol was a strong, kind, and loving person. Last November she was diagnosed with stage 4 metestatic Lung Cancer. She didn't feel sorry for herself. She took it as a challenge and was out to beat it!!

Having to leave her full time job and volunteer time at the local hospital, my Mother has gone through several types of Chemotherapy and she has just finished with radiation. Unfortunately, the cancer has spread. The doctors have discontinued both the chemo and radiation.

She has an estimated life expectancy of 2 months. There is nothing more to do but pray for her comfort and strength. She has had several weeks in the hospital and will be discharged tomorrow to a local Nursing Facility for physical therapy, then they will be switching her to hospice. They hope to keep her strong for as long as possible.

The reason for this page is to try to raise funds for mom's out of pocket medical expenses and the bills she can no longer pay because of not being able to work. I know it will be less stressful for her, knowing they are taken care of. We are also hoping to be able to bring my brothers and their families from New York and Arizona to NC to be with her.

I am her only daughter and I live 2 hours away. I have quit my job and put my life on hold to take care of Mom (not that I mind) I have been by her side for the past 5 weeks and many weeks before that with a few weekends off. I have been able to spend quality time with my Mother and I hope and pray my brothers will be able to do so as well so she can pass peacfully, sourrounded by her family.

****Hi. I have a Mom update. Mom is so upset she won't be able to meet James Patterson! He has been her favorite author for YEARS!!! I got her VIP tickets for Christmas. Paul and I will go instead. I will get her book signed but it won't be the same without her. :-(

4/1/13 Mom has decided to go on hospice. She just can't fight anymore. I'm not sure when she will get transferred. We have to have $2160.00 down payment for the first 2 weeks. It is then 155.00 per day. Does anyone know of agencies who can help with those expenses? That's the CO PAY! I have to speak with the social worker tomorrow about placement. I'm in sticker shock!!!! Please keep her in your prayers.
Jill

story:
Short Summary

The Windham Harm Reduction Coalition (WHRC), works to empower and make a difference in the lives of drug users, commercial sex workers, and their partners and families through offering comprehensive harm reduction services, education, and training. 

What We Need & What You Get

WHRC volunteers, Molly Kochenburger and Kim Adamski are working together to establish a sex worker outreach program, to meet the health and safety needs of sex workers in Northeast Connecticut. These women need your support help make this possible.

Kim Adamski says, "Harm reduction is an incredibly important part of public health. Sex workers are a  vulnerable population whose health needs are often overlooked because of the stigma associated with their work.  Our program is working to empower and improve the health of these women and their families."

Your donation will help Kim and Molly with their efforts to organize self-defense workshops, activity nights, and harm reduction trainings for sex workers in Northeast Connecticut.

The Impact

WHRC is a volunteer run community health organization. Our agency provides free confidential HIV prevention and other health services to over 230 individuals in Northeast Connecticut. WHRC currently offers the following health services free of charge:                                                            

-Sex Worker Self Defense Trainings                                                        

-Harm Reduction Trainings for Sex Workers                                                      

-Syringe Exchange                                                                                               

-HIV Testing and Counseling Referrals                                                          

-Drug Overdose Prevention / Safer Use Trainings                                                           

-LGBTQ Youth Suicide Prevention Workshops                                                            

-Drug Treatment Referrals                                                                                    

-Housing Referrals

A donation of $5.00 will pay for harm reduction supplies for one woman for a week.

A donation of $10.00 will pay for a portion of a harm reduction training.

A donation of $20.00 will pay for a HIV Test for one woman.     

Other Ways You Can Help

Unable to give at this time but want to help? Please consider organizing a fundraiser to benefit Windham Harm Reduction Coalition. For more information on how to organize a fundraiser please e-mail us at: windhamharmreductioncoalition@gmail.com.

  Check out our webiste for more information about our work.

www.windhamhrc.org

On behalf of the Windham Harm Reduction Coalition, thank you for your contribution towards our life saving work.

story:
Hey! Welcome to my fundraising campaign that I'm hoping will help fund for my "reverse" boob job!

My name is Ian Carter Smith... I'm 33 years old, and I am a trans boy. On January 1, 2013, I came out to the world through YouTube about being transgender. Since then I have hit a lot of snags and have ran into a lot of road blocks in my transition... mostly in regards to discrimination of health insurance companies when it comes to covering transgender services. (For instance if you watch this video you'll see that I think my insurance covers my transition because that's what my psychiatrist told me... well, I learned that it DOESN'T!!!) So here I am... asking for some support... pleading for someone to help set me free!

And by no means do I want for you to go more broke than you may already be (I know! "Times iz hard right now!")... $1, $5, $10... any amount can go a long way.

Still not sure you want to donate? Understandable. Maybe you need to get to know me more. You can follow me and all of my progress on YouTube at: www.youtube.com/user/iancartertransition. I will be recording my transition from beginning to end!

Also, by helping me fund my surgery... you will be helping other trans guys fund their surgeries in the future. For if my campaign is successful in raising funds for my own surgery, I pledge that I will pay it forward by continuing my fundraising efforts to help other trans guys fund their surgeries. You can even watch the video where I make that pledge on my YouTube channel!

Lastly, if you have time... visit my other attempt at fundraising for my surgery at: http://www.cafepress.com/iancarterstransitionfund The only thing about this attempt is that I only get a few dollars for each item I sell. So as you can see... I NEED HELP!!!

Help this boy become a man!

 

Thank you so much! And bless all of you!

-Ian Carter Smith

story:
Maggie's Story

Maggie McCombs turned 21 years of age December 27th, 2011. She loved to work out, run and enjoyed spending time with friends and family and especially my brother (JC Escamilla). The two began dating in early November and it seemed that a beautiful relationship was blossoming. On January 8, 2012 Maggie and JC Escamilla where leaving Planet Fitness where JC worked and Maggie was a Club Member when they where ambushed by an alleged stalker. Unfortunately JC did not survive the brutal attack but Maggie did. Maggie was critically injured after she was shot five times by her alleged stalker. After enduring extensive medical procedures the doctors could no longer do anything for Maggie she was paralyzed from neck down. After months of agonizing surgeries she is now home from the hospital and is faced with extreme physical and emotional challenges, but that is not all, her parents are struggling to have there home remodeled in order to provide Maggie with just basic care like a shower and bathroom that can accommodate her. They also do not have a vehicle to transport Maggie to her doctor appointments and much needed therapy sessions. They are also faced with mounting medical bills and the financial responsibility that they will need for the lifetime care Maggie will so desperately need. This is why we have set up this campaign. Maggie's story is a story of hope and love. I hope you find it in your hearts to help Maggie and her family.

What your donation will do

The family is in desperate need of a wheel chair accessible vehicle, for daily transportation. The overwhelming medical bills and home modifications have made it very difficult for the family to purchase a vehicle on their own. Your contrubution would go a long way to helping Maggie piece her life together and make the simple task of getting around that much easier. 

The Impact

Having a wheel chair accesible vehicle with a ramp and lift will make the daily task of getting around one less challenge that the McCombs family will have to face. Maggie is doing her part to fight to get her life back to normal and transportaion would have a great impact.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, and that is OK. You can still help! Sharing Maggies's story with your family and friends by word of mouth, email, facebook or other social media will help get the word out and reach the biggest audience possible.

story:
My Story

Hi. My name is Lynda. I am a holistic esthetician, artist and energy healer. I am deeply interested in helping others in need, learning new ways to expand my knowledge of energy work and plant spirit healing. 


I was recently accepted into the wonderful nonprofit organization Healer2Healer based in NYC, whose volunteers of alternative medicine bring their healing skills to rural indigenous communities worldwide. 


I will be traveling with a small volunteer group to Peru, staying at the Paititi Institue in Iquitos. From there we will be traveling to Cahuide in the Amazon Rainforest where we will be giving free health services to the local communitiy. I will be offering Reiki along with using vibrational plant and mineral-based medicine. I need your help in raising funds for my trip! 


The Impact

Many of the local communities that we will be serving are in great need of healing as they have often been marginalized, and have no health care. Healer2Healer volunteers (that include acupuncturists, Reiki practitioners and massage therapists) will be working with Western style practitioners for five days in a Community health clinic in Cahuide. The triage is expecting to treat 2,500–4,000 patients. In addition, we also have an amazing opportunity to learn from these communities including:


• Sacred plant ceremonies

• Connect with nature in a deep way

• Stay at The Praititi Institue for the Preservation of the Amazon Rainforest & Indigenous Culture

• Learn about plant medicine and other ancient indigenous healing traditions

• Connect with other alternative health practitioners

• Experience and learn about sustainable living

• Visti local Amazonian tribes to learn about their way of life and experience their skills and art


What I Need & What You Get

I will be traveling from August 14–August 28th. As all H2H volunteers are responsible for their own expenses (travel, lodging and supplies), I greatly appreciate any financial support you can offer, no matter how small. This site allows you to give as much or as little as you want. I also appreciate your consideration and blessings! In return, you will be part of my journey by enabling me to treat many people in need along with giving me the opportunity to deepen my knowledge of plant and energy healing. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word through email, Facebook, or visiting my website (listed below) to purchase art. Any and all efforts get my deepest gratitude!


Many blessings!

Lynda

Lynda D'Amico Fine Art

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!


And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Health on The Rise is a health awareness music & entertainment charity event produced by The Executive staff of Y.A.I.D.T.S., Inc & Health On The Rise and in unique partnership with Slowbucks Ent and Doc Checker, Health on The Rise will render critical support to under privileged communities!

Through our partners Doc Checker and Slowbucks, Health on The Rise seeks to heighten the awareness of preventable health problems and encourage early detection and treatment of illnesses and diseases such as Mental illness, cancer, diabetes, heart disease, autoimmune diseases, HIV, AIDS and so many others that plague us as a nation. In addition to raising awareness, the events purpose is also to raise funds for charity, 10 to 20 percent of which will go to charities such as N.A.M.I. (National Alliance on Mental Illness), American Cancer Society, American Diabetes Association, and many more.

From left to right: Sandra Nicoleau, Sterling Cleveland, Lorenzo Muzerwa Nicoleau, Roderick Hutcherson Supporting the Walk To Stop Diabetes.



Through awareness, Health on The Rise will bridge the gap between people and the road to healthier living by providing them with knowledge and understanding of all things health to promote a lifestyle of prevention and wellness through music concerts, entertainment and grassroots campaign efforts within the community. The primary goal of our music & entertainment event is to raise awareness for the importance of good health and wellness while encouraging access to healthcare providers by a grassroots community campaign efforts starting initially within the Tristate area.


THE EVENT

TITLE OF THE PROJECT:

Health On The Rise Presents: Health Awareness & Sandy Relief Charitable Concert

NAME OF THE ORGANIZATION:

Y.A.I.D.T.S., Inc., Health On The Rise, Slowbucks Ent. & Doc Checker.

LOCATION OF THE PROJECT: MCU Park Coney Island Brooklyn, New York

DATES: May 2014

Your generosity will enable us to host an event that will be the combination of health care professionals, executives, therapist and celebrity guest speakers, free clinics, vendors, charitable organizations, and performing artist under one roof, sharing and dispensing a well of health care knowledge and information for all in attendance, and make it an explosive enjoyable experience all at the same time. This is a great opportunity for us all to band together and encourage each other to be our healthiest and get involved in prevention, care, and best practices when it comes to daily health and more specific health conditions, creating an atmosphere conducive to great “Health on The Rise” for us all.

Other Ways You Can Help

Most of you will be able to donate as we would like. Some may not. But no one is limited to just the monetary help we seek. In addition to your financial contribution, you can also help in the following ways:

  • Spread the word. Tell your family, friends, associates, bosses, ect. Have them give along with you
  • Share our pages and links on your social media
  • Use the Indiegogo sharing tools to make it easier
  • Make sure to purchase a ticket to the event date of your choice, and have a wonderful time creating healtheir minds full of awareness


 HEALTH ON THE RISE/ MCU PARK HEALT

story:
*** The family of Baby Brystal did not ask me to do this, I was just moved by the story and figured 'why not?' After all, it takes a village, right?  

All money raised will go directly to the family ***


Bandages for Brystal

Brystal is a sweet little baby in Arizona who happens to have a horrible skin disease called rDEB, aka, Butterfly skin. 

The smallest irritation will cause her skin to blister and therefore she needs to have sterile bandages covering them all the time.

Her parents have to change those bandages for her daily because she is a baby. Would you be able to change your child's bandages while they cried in pain? 

Can you imagine? I sure can't

Her mom writes a blog about it here: http://brystalandeb.blogspot.com/

You cannot read the entries without admiring her mom and her family for their good humor and coping skills.

 

What They Need & What You Get

Mom and Dad need to make sure that their daughter is always bandaged up so she can get on with being a happy little baby. They also need to be there for the other two kids. 

This kind of constant medical care adds up fast, so let's help them out a little. At least during baby's first year, when it's one of the most formative years!

Any and all funds raised will go directly to the family along with a card from all of "Us".

They can use it to help defray some of the medical bills, and to buy medical supplies for Brystal. Hopefully they will also be able to buy something nice for the two older siblings!

It would just be nice to take a tiny bit of pressure off Mom and Dad so they can relax a little with their kids for a minute. 

If you've read this far, I thank you so much :)

story:
Short Summary

Sweet Rosalie nearly drowned on June 6th. She is in the hospital fighting for her life and every day is a struggle of survival. Please pass this page on to all you know who have God's ear.

For daily updates and more information you can click on the link below where it has already gathered more than 25,000 prayer warriors in just over 2 weeks.

http://www.facebook.com/pages/Please-Pray-for-Rosalie/113775598763720

All of the funding will go to the family to help pay for medical expenses and lost work as they stay by her side every day.

The Impact

Rosalie has been in the hospital for more than 2 weeks and the financial toll on her family is buidling up along with the emotional hardship.  This will help relieve some of the financial burden

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can't help:

  • Please Pray for Rosalie
  • Help get the word out to support this sweet family

story:
Hi my name is Justin Oien. I am a 17 year old road cyclist, and I race for the Monster Media/SC VELO p/b MRI Cycling Team. I have been selected by USA Cycling, the official governing body for all disciplines of competitive cycling in the United States, and responsible for identifying, training and selecting cyclist to represent the United States in international competition, .to race with the USAC Junior National Team. I will go first to Rouyn-Noranda, Quebec, Canada to participate in a prestigious 6 day-7 stage race called the Tour De L'Abitibi, where teams of 17 and 18 year olds from all over the world come to compete. Many of the best European junior development cycling programs bring their 17-18 year old teams to this race to test their mettle. After L'Abitibi, USA Cycling wants me to fly to Brussels, Belgium where they want me to train with the top USA Junior National Development Coaches and race for three weeks against the European juniors. The USA Cycling agenda has me “off racing” for a total of 34 days in Canada and Belgium.

The perspective of USA Cycling is that this is a development program to cultivate the future Olympic cyclists of the United States. It is essentially a training camp. America’s best coaches do the teaching, we, the junior riders are the students and do the training, and the Belgians provide the stiffest competition in the world. Cycling is the national pass-time of Belgium. As for the “training camp”, the travel, food and housing, and coaching etc. are not cheap or free. USA Cycling looks for talent and invites select riders.
I am expected to come up with $1000 for housing, race entry fees , and the salaries of the coaches for L'Abitibi. I am also expected to get myself to Rouyn-Noranda so there is the airfare for $700. In addition, I also have to bring my own bike to L'Abitibi, so there is round-trip shipping of $300 for my bike. I will be leaving for Belgium directly from Rouyn-Noranda and I am responsible for my round-trip airfare to Belgium plus food and housing of $70 per day up to a maximum of $700 for a total of $3700.

Neither I nor my parents have anywhere near the necessary funds for me to be able to participate in this incredible opportunity. As such I am reaching out to various entities which I have been informed offer financial assistance to families in regards to this sort of dilemma. I would sincerely appreciate any help you can offer as I attempt to go out and represent the United States on an international cycling stage.

Thank you for your consideration

The Impact

With your help I will be well on my way to achieving my goal of racing as a pro all over the world. The money will be going to pay for the expenses listed above. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can't help.

You can help by sharing this project on social media sites and to your friends and family.  

And that’s all there is to it.

Seriously thank you so much.

story:
First of all, I would have placed a picture of myself with my Partner but she threatened to do nasty things to my Gentleman's sausage if I did, so here's a picture of our cat Moogle chewing his own tail.

Parents, you know how much stuff you needed when your own child was on the way, and I'm sure most of you know how time seems to just pass really quickly when planning on what to get your new bundle of joy.

Well we're in the same boat and we're pretty stuck in terms of getting things together which is why I'm doing this for our first child. Some of you reading this know me personally so this is a great way to help us out instead of trying to find something to buy, just fund this instead, we'll do the hard work of going to the shops, enduring queues, waiting for packages etc.

  • Nappies/Diapers
  • Bottles
  • Bottle sterilizer
  • Formua
  • Clothes
  • Pram
  • Basket
  • Wipes
  • Bathing goods
  • Toys
  • Changing Mat
  • Baby Bath
  • Changing Bag/hold-all

The list goes on and on, it's crazy how much stuff you need for a newborn.

Others reading this will not know me or my partner Sarah at all but may relate to the stressful times leading upto the birth of thier own child and may feel the need to help out.

At the end of the day, this isn't some crusade to send a beleaguered bus monitor on vacation (which turned out to be a pretty nice lump sum last time I checked) or a journalistic experiment to fund lunches for 50 days (Hi Gizmodo) but simply something to ease the financial burden of buying things for a child, especially in this current climate where it's hard to make a few coins to put in your back pocket. Every pledge goes directly to baby goods and not to increasing my game collection on Steam or something.

What I can promise is that any pledge, no matter the size will be greatly appreciated, not only by myself, not only by my partner but also by our first child (though may take a few years before they understand fully how this works). Additionally anyone who pledges on or above the perk threshold will also get an awesome token of thanks posted out to you no matter where in the world you are.

Those wondering on the timescale of this, well bambino is due mid November so realistically we're looking around September to gather all the information and do the tokens of thanks to all those who donated. This should give us enough time between the end of the campaign and the estimated birth date to sort things out.

Finally, thanks for reading, we do hope you help out but we appreciate you taking the time to hear us out.

Thanks Again,

Neil and Sarah + Bump (and 4 cats).

story:
Natural Harvest Cooking Show Series

A collection of semen-based recipes

 

ABOUT THE PROJECT:

Semen is not only nutritious, but it also has a wonderful texture and amazing cooking properties. Like fine wine and cheeses, the taste of semen is complex and dynamic. Semen is inexpensive to produce and is commonly available in many, if not most, homes and restaurants. Despite all of these positive qualities, semen remains neglected as a food. 

This series plans to change that. 

Once you overcome any initial hesitation, you will be surprised to learn how wonderful semen is in the kitchen. Semen is an exciting ingredient that can give every dish you make an interesting twist. If you are a passionate cook and are not afraid to experiment with new ingredients - you will love this series!

Our sexy female host will show you how to create some of the tastiest dishes you’re mouth has ever experienced. With recipes ranging from appetizers like Slightly Saltier Caviar and Man Made Oysters to entrees like Tuna Sashimi with Homemade Dipping Sauce and Noodles with Special Spicy Sauce to deserts like Tiramisu Surprise and Spunky Candied Pecans, it has all the "ingredients" for a hugely successful series; just throw in a gorgeous and sexy chef in nothing but a kitchen apron and it will be a hit.

This project is a coming to life of the original book "Natural Harvest", a completely legitimate cook book with an interesting slant - all the recipes happen to have the ingredient of semen (most recipes require 1-3 tablespoons fresh semen).  The recipes are elegant and the photography sophisticated, and as hilariously funny as it is to bring out at parties, it is in fact a great collection of recipes.   

We have teamed up with the author to turn it into a series of episodes with a sexy yet sophisticated model as our host chef, and present the product to networks such as HBO2, Playboy, Spice, Vivid, etc., for broadcast.  We feel that the show would be a huge success, and news of such a show would spread virally across all platforms of media.

This specific fund-raising will provide a budget to complete a pilot presentation for network pitches.

 

ABOUT THE PRODUCERS:

This series will be developed & produced by professionals who work in the TV and Film business on a daily basis, who have won and been nominated for multiple awards, including Emmy Awards and Webby Awards, and the quality will equal that of any major network show.

 

PRESS: 

Tosh.0 Book Club:

http://tosh.comedycentral.com/video-clips/tosh-0-book-club---natural-harvest

MSN:

http://now.msn.com/sperm-cookbook-finally-available-for-your-e-reader

LA Weekly:

http://blogs.laweekly.com/squidink/2011/11/natural_harvest_semen_cookbook.php

BuzzFeed Food: 

http://www.buzzfeed.com/jimbohits/natural-harvest-a-collection-of-semen-based-reci-5fqb

GoodReads:

http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/5830947-natural-harvest---a-collection-of-semen-based-recipes

story:
A Tongan mother holds her young son in her arms in the shade of a palm tree, rocking back and forth as she looks out over the turquoise blue waters and white sand beaches of the South Pacific Island, a place where she and countless ancestors have always lived. In spite of the incredible beauty displayed before her, the cool breeze blowing off the ocean is not enough to cool her son's ever growing fever, nor is it able to drown out his soft moans. She is familiar with this moment, seeing it played out countless times before on this remote island. Her son is dying and there is no emergency helicopter or ambulance to call, for they have no phones or electricity, and there is no supply ships scheduled to visit for at least another month. She looks at the swollen arm and the small cut that had gradually turned into a deadly infection, one that she knew was easy enough to cure with the proper medicine, but not here. Her island home is hundreds of miles away from the main island Hospital of Tongatupu, thirty miles away from the nearest remote Health Centre. She knows that putting other family member's lives at risk to cross open seas in a small motorboat is not an option. She looks one more time across the blue waters, hoping to see mercy coming on the horizon.

Sea Mercy

Bringing health care to remote islands in the South Pacific

Whether it is an infection, respiratory illness, or any of the hundred small illnesses that can turn deadly without proper care, the above life story is played out thousands of times unnecessarily on the remote islands of the South Pacific. But this time she will know that "Sea Mercy" is coming on the horizon.

Sea Mercy's target community in the South Pacific consists of 10 island nations with a combined population of 2.5 million people living on 2,500 islands spread across 8,000,000 square miles of ocean. These island nations are striving to build a modern health care infrastructure on their larger, primary islands. However, with no roads, power lines, or phone systems on the smaller, remote islands, those whom live on them will not have access to the same level of health care services that are being established on the main islands for five to ten years. This disconnect creates an incredible disparity in infant mortality rates, immunization rates, and a reduced health and longevity compared to those on the primary islands. The need is urgent and there is a solution, but it requires your help.

Sea Mercy (www.seamercy.org) is a 501(c)3 non-profit charity that was created to "stand in the gap" for these remote islanders until their island nations' health care infrastructure can meet their needs. Sea Mercy is a Floating Health Care Clinic (FHCC) staffed by a continual rotation of volunteer doctors, dentists, nurses and staff who care enough to give of their time and lives to meet these needs.

President & Founders

Richard and Stephanie Hackett, President and Founders of the Sea Mercy Program have spent over thirty years of their lives preparing to launch this important and much needed program. With successful profit and non-profit corporate experience, they bring a mature and tested leadership to the Sea Mercy organization (for a detailed bio click here).

Tasks Completed

  • 501(c)3 status acquired
  • Program developed and operational budget determined 
  • Presentation of the program to South Pacific island nations
  • Initial Partner Island selection and approval (Tonga)
  • Established Health Care Volunteer Partnerships (Click here) and launched outreach initiatives
  • FHCC Vessel purchase commitment
  • Partnership with Medical Supplies source

Our Current Need

Based on the Founders' prior experience in establishing and funding a non-profit organization, it takes a minimum of one year of dedicated efforts to achieve the necessary traction and approval with corporate and government funding sources. We have begun the submission process for grant and foundation funding to provide the financial support needed to operate a FHCC for 5+ years, but because the review and approval cycle can be one year or longer, this will require us to delay the launch of the program until 2014. Because this program is needed in 2013, this campaign is seeking to raise the minimum funds required to deliver and operate a Sea Mercy Floating Health Care Clinic for the first 12 months (the requested funding amount), for the Kingdom of Tonga. We understand this is a large funding request, but all things are possible when we work together. We hope with your support we can delliver this much needed program in 2013.

All funds raised will focus on the following:

Floating Heal Care Clinic Operations  (62% of the budget)
Like a hospital or clinic, the operational costs of establishing and operating a facility is the greatest expense. The challenge for those in the South Pacific is that a hospital or health clinic cannot be built, supplied and staffed on every remote island. The most affordable way to meet those needs is through a Floating Health Care Clinic regularly visiting each remote island. The funds are used to ensure the safety and needs of our volunteers are being met while aboard the FHCC, that the FHCC is able to deliver those volunteers and supplies to the remote islands that we serve, and that our local island citizens are treated with the utmost care.

Medical Supplies (12% of the budget)
Without the medical supplies, the FHCC is just a floating advisory vessel, not a medical treatment clinic. Working with our medical supplies partner (MedShare), we will maintain a one year reserve of medical supplies stationed on our island nation partner to ensure that each rotation of health care volunteers are fully equipped to deliver the much needed health care services. Additional or excess supplies will be provided to our island partner for distribution to their local hospitals and health centers as needed.

Travel Expense Assistance for Volunteers (10% of the budget)
Although most of our short-term volunteers cover their own travel expenses, circumstances may require us to cover some of our "emergency" and/or "specialists" volunteer's travel expenses in order to maintain a fully staffed FHCC rotation due to last minute cancellations.

Island Nation Based Operations (9% of the budget)
Although a small percentage of our budget, our local medical supplies storage, resupply and distribution facility is crucial to our successful ongoing operations and maintaining effective communication with our island nation partner and local health care staff. This also includes key personnel to manage and direct the FHCC operations locally.

US Based Operations (8% of the budget)
Although volunteers staff most of our US based operations, there are operational costs, legal fees, and personnel that require financial resources to operate. This includes the screening and selection of the volunteer health care staff for rotations on the FHCC (doctors, dentists, ophthalmologists, nurses, pharmacy technicians) 

It Takes A Family...

Support for Sea Mercy is already growing quickly as more and more people learn about our program and take on the dream themselves, but it will take a large family of volunteers and sponsors to connect our infrastructure and distribution system with all the people of the South Pacific. The Founders of Sea Mercy have committed to the purchase of the vessel for the Floating Health Care Clinic, once outside funding sources for Sea Mercy are able to support the day-to-day operations of the Sea Mercy program. Your support and financial assistance will expedite the implementation of this program in 2013 and through the life of the program.   

"Thank You" Perks

Meeting a need can, in itself, be reward enough, but we at Sea Mercy want to make giving fun and to leave you with something extra. For small to large donations, here's what we came up with:

$25 or higher sponsors

Receive a Kindle version of the new Christian/Suspense/Thriller novel "The Eyes of the Heart" and the Historical Fiction (Action & Adventure) novel, "The Black Dragons" by Richard A Hackett Jr. to download to your Kindle, phone or computer. All proceeds from the sale of these two novels also goes to support Sea Mercy, so please refer a friend.

$100 or higher sponsors

Be a permanent part of something amazing! All supporters who donate $100 or more will have your name added to our permanent "Founding Sponsor" list on the Sea Mercy website and also receive the above e-books.

$3,000 or higher sponsors

If you are "all in" with us at this sponsor level, then we want to invite you to spend 2 weeks with us on the FHCC as we travel between the islands. This will include all your food and accommodations on the vessel (just like one of the crew so be ready to roll up your sleeves to help). You will also receive a Founding Sponsor listing on the website. Be a part of the start of something amazing with us, and witness first hand the needs that Sea Mercy is meeting in the South Pacific! 

Additional Areas Where You Can Help

Please use the Indiegogo share tools to help get the word out about what Sea Mercy is doing in the South Pacific. If you have expertise in the areas below that you would like to share, or relationships with people that you believe would benefit from a connection to the staff of Sea Mercy, in any of the below health care or support areas, please contact us. It will be met with great appreciation.

  • Additional Health Care Supplies - Medical, Dental, Eye
  • In-Kind Corporate Sponsorships - Health Care Related is best
  • Sea Mercy Networking relationships (shipping, airlines, sailing)
  • Volunteering for US based or island based needs

Thank you for your support, and please feel free to email us with any questions.

Sea Mercy
www.seamercy.org
info@seamercy.org

Press

Articles

Cruising Compass Website of the Week: http://bwsailing.com/cc/2012/11/27/the-real-call-of-the-south-pacific/

Links

Become a Sea Mercy Volunteer: http://www.seamercy.org/node/48
story_txt:
A Tongan mother holds her young son in her arms in the shade of a palm tree, rocking back and forth as she looks out over the turquoise blue waters and white sand beaches of the South Pacific Island, a place where she and countless ancestors have always lived. In spite of the incredible beauty displayed before her, the cool breeze blowing off the ocean is not enough to cool her son's ever growing fever, nor is it able to drown out his soft moans. She is familiar with this moment, seeing it played out countless times before on this remote island. Her son is dying and there is no emergency helicopter or ambulance to call, for they have no phones or electricity, and there is no supply ships scheduled to visit for at least another month. She looks at the swollen arm and the small cut that had gradually turned into a deadly infection, one that she knew was easy enough to cure with the proper medicine, but not here. Her island home is hundreds of miles away from the main island Hospital of Tongatupu, thirty miles away from the nearest remote Health Centre. She knows that putting other family member's lives at risk to cross open seas in a small motorboat is not an option. She looks one more time across the blue waters, hoping to see mercy coming on the horizon.
Sea Mercy
Bringing health care to remote islands in the South Pacific

Whether it is an infection, respiratory illness, or any of the hundred small illnesses that can turn deadly without proper care, the above life story is played out thousands of times unnecessarily on the remote islands of the South Pacific. But this time she will know that "Sea Mercy" is coming on the horizon.

Sea Mercy's target community in the South Pacific consists of 10 island nations with a combined population of 2.5 million people living on 2,500 islands spread across 8,000,000 square miles of ocean. These island nations are striving to build a modern health care infrastructure on their larger, primary islands. However, with no roads, power lines, or phone systems on the smaller, remote islands, those whom live on them will not have access to the same level of health care services that are being established on the main islands for five to ten years. This disconnect creates an incredible disparity in infant mortality rates, immunization rates, and a reduced health and longevity compared to those on the primary islands. The need is urgent and there is a solution, but it requires your help.
Sea Mercy (www.seamercy.org) is a 501(c)3 non-profit charity that was created to "stand in the gap" for these remote islanders until their island nations' health care infrastructure can meet their needs. Sea Mercy is a Floating Health Care Clinic (FHCC) staffed by a continual rotation of volunteer doctors, dentists, nurses and staff who care enough to give of their time and lives to meet these needs.

President & Founders
Richard and Stephanie Hackett, President and Founders of the Sea Mercy Program have spent over thirty years of their lives preparing to launch this important and much needed program. With successful profit and non-profit corporate experience, they bring a mature and tested leadership to the Sea Mercy organization (for a detailed bio click here).
Tasks Completed

501(c)3 status acquired
Program developed and operational budget determined 
Presentation of the program to South Pacific island nations
Initial Partner Island selection and approval (Tonga)
Established Health Care Volunteer Partnerships (Click here) and launched outreach initiatives
FHCC Vessel purchase commitment
Partnership with Medical Supplies source
Our Current Need
Based on the Founders' prior experience in establishing and funding a non-profit organization, it takes a minimum of one year of dedicated efforts to achieve the necessary traction and approval with corporate and government funding sources. We have begun the submission process for grant and foundation funding to provide the financial support needed to operate a FHCC for 5+ years, but because the review and approval cycle can be one year or longer, this will require us to delay the launch of the program until 2014. Because this program is needed in 2013, this campaign is seeking to raise the minimum funds required to deliver and operate a Sea Mercy Floating Health Care Clinic for the first 12 months (the requested funding amount), for the Kingdom of Tonga. We understand this is a large funding request, but all things are possible when we work together. We hope with your support we can delliver this much needed program in 2013.
All funds raised will focus on the following:
Floating Heal Care Clinic Operations  (62% of the budget)Like a hospital or clinic, the operational costs of establishing and operating a facility is the greatest expense. The challenge for those in the South Pacific is that a hospital or health clinic cannot be built, supplied and staffed on every remote island. The most affordable way to meet those needs is through a Floating Health Care Clinic regularly visiting each remote island. The funds are used to ensure the safety and needs of our volunteers are being met while aboard the FHCC, that the FHCC is able to deliver those volunteers and supplies to the remote islands that we serve, and that our local island citizens are treated with the utmost care.

Additional or excess supplies will be provided to our island partner for distribution to their local hospitals and health centers as needed.
Travel Expense Assistance for Volunteers (10% of the budget)Although most of our short-term volunteers cover their own travel expenses, circumstances may require us to cover some of our "emergency" and/or "specialists" volunteer's travel expenses in order to maintain a fully staffed FHCC rotation due to last minute cancellations.
Island Nation Based Operations (9% of the budget)Although a small percentage of our budget, our local medical supplies storage, resupply and distribution facility is crucial to our successful ongoing operations and maintaining effective communication with our island nation partner and local health care staff. This also includes key personnel to manage and direct the FHCC operations locally.
US Based Operations (8% of the budget)Although volunteers staff most of our US based operations, there are operational costs, legal fees, and personnel that require financial resources to operate. This includes the screening and selection of the volunteer health care staff for rotations on the FHCC (doctors, dentists, ophthalmologists, nurses, pharmacy technicians)

story:
Right before Thanksgiving 2011, I was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. I've had surgery, chemo & radiation with more treatments to come. Since I have no medical insurance, there's a mountain of unpaid medical bills. I hope you can help a bit.

My daughter & I wrote a blog that details this ordeal. Take a few minutes & read it here: http://www.ecuytt.com/Blog---Updates.html?entry=the-cursed-c-word.

I've tried to make a positive difference for my school, East Carolina University, by creating & maintaining a website called ECUYTT (East Carolina University: Yesterday, Today, Tomorrow). There's no registration required to read the website & there are no ads.

I have no "perks" to offer you, so my appeal is to your kindness & compassion for a fellow human being that is in need.

story:
Our Story

When surfing the internet looking for retreats for people who are ill and terminally ill we found very little for adults and their young families, most were especially for children. We found one trust which was specially aimed at adults but only if they met certain criteria for instance families on low incomes. All adults who suffer  cancers are all equal in my books and whether they are on a low or high income this suddenly stops when they are diagnosed but they still have bills, rent and mortgages to pay so they dont lose their homes. A holiday for most people is out of the question as money they do have coming in is spent on household bills and keeping a family. 


THE IMPACT


We would love to raise enough funds to buy or build a small villa or log cabin for patients to use free of charge with their familes in between treatments or after treatment. This would give people time to spend with their children and create happy memories. This will also give our family a project to focus on knowing we can help other people going through the trauma of diagnosis and give them something to look forward to during endless hospital visits and treatments.

Eventually we would like to have a retreat in north France so it is accessible via car and ferry as well as the Euro tunnel. Also secondary to this we would also like to have one in the the Scottish Borders which would be quite central for all in the uk with gorgeous surroundings.

What We Need & What You Get

What we need to get started is enough cash to buy a small piece of land in the borders or North Scotland and start raising funds for the build. If our aim is not met we will continue fundraising until we have enough. We can buy land to build a log cabin on for around 40 000. We aim to raise the rest by fundraising campaigns.

We really need your help. I promise to keep you updated on our progress.

Other Ways You Can Help

PLEASE POST THIS CAMPAIGN ON YOU'RE FACEBOOK, TWITTER, YOU TUBE AND ANY OTHER SITES YOU HAVE ACCESS TO. PLEASE ALSO PASS ON TO YOU'RE FRIENDS AND FAMILY. WE WOULD BE VERY GRATEFUL FOR ANY FEEDBACK AND SUGGESTIONS FROM ALL OF YOU.
